text.headline: History of Rome
text.text: A timeline of key events in the Roman Republic and Empire.

text.headline: Roman Republic
text.text:
The Roman Republic spanned from 509 BCE to 27 BCE, a period marked by profound political and social transformations. The Republic saw the creation of the Senate and republican magistracies, offering an innovative political structure for its time.

The Punic Wars against Carthage, notably the victories of Scipio Africanus, expanded Roman territory and consolidated its power in the Mediterranean. Internal conflicts, such as the civil wars between Marius and Sulla, and later between Julius Caesar and Pompey, destabilized the Republic and weakened its institutions. The Roman Senate, despite its efforts to maintain the balance of power, could not contain the ambition of influential generals and politicians.

Julius Caesar, after his victory over Pompey, established a de facto dictatorship, paving the way for the end of the Republic. His assassination in 44 BCE led to another civil war between his heirs, Octavian and Mark Antony. Octavian's victory at the Battle of Actium in 31 BCE marked the end of the Republic and the beginning of the Empire. Augustus's reforms definitively transformed Rome, transitioning it from a tumultuous republic to a stable and powerful empire.

text.headline: Julio-Claudian Dynasty
text.text:
The Julio-Claudian dynasty begins with Augustus, the first emperor of Rome, who ruled from 27 BCE to 14 CE. Augustus ended the civil wars and established the Pax Romana, a period of peace and prosperity that lasted over two centuries. He reformed the administration, strengthened the army, and promoted arts and literature.

Tiberius, his successor, ruled from 14 to 37. His reign was marked by prudent management of public finances and a defensive foreign policy. Caligula, who ruled from 37 to 41, is known for his cruelty and extravagance, leading to his assassination. Claudius, who ruled from 41 to 54, expanded the Empire by conquering Britain and implemented significant administrative reforms.

Nero, the last Julio-Claudian emperor, ruled from 54 to 68. His reign was marked by excesses, the persecution of Christians, and the Great Fire of Rome in 64. He committed suicide in 68 after a revolt by provincial governors, ending the Julio-Claudian dynasty.

text.headline: Flavian Dynasty
text.text:
The Flavian dynasty was founded by Vespasian after the Year of the Four Emperors in 69. Vespasian, who ruled from 69 to 79, stabilized the Empire after a period of chaos and began the construction of the Colosseum, the largest amphitheater in Rome. He reorganized finances and strengthened the Empire's borders.

His eldest son, Titus, ruled from 79 to 81 and is famous for completing the Colosseum and managing the catastrophe of the Vesuvius eruption in 79, which destroyed Pompeii and Herculaneum. Domitian, Titus's younger brother, ruled from 81 to 96. His reign was marked by military campaigns on the frontiers and administrative reforms.

Domitian was an efficient administrator, but his authoritarianism and persecutions of senators and Christians led to his assassination in 96, marking the end of the Flavian dynasty.

text.headline: Nerva–Antonine Dynasty
text.text:
The Nerva–Antonine dynasty, also known as the Antonine dynasty, is often considered the golden age of the Roman Empire. It began with Nerva in 96, who adopted Trajan as his successor.

Trajan ruled from 98 to 117 and expanded the Empire to its greatest territorial extent, conquering Dacia (present-day Romania) and leading successful campaigns against the Parthians. Hadrian, his successor, ruled from 117 to 138 and consolidated the Empire's borders, notably building Hadrian's Wall in Britain. He was also known for his travels throughout the Empire and his administrative reforms.

Antoninus Pius, who ruled from 138 to 161, maintained peace and prosperity without engaging in major wars. Marcus Aurelius, philosopher and emperor, ruled from 161 to 180 and is known for his Stoic writings, 'Meditations.' His reign was marked by military conflicts on the frontiers, notably the Marcomannic Wars. Commodus, son of Marcus Aurelius, ruled from 180 to 192. His reign degenerated into tyranny and extravagance, leading to his assassination and a period of chaos.

events.territory: Rome, present-day Italy, Spain, Anatolia, North Africa

text.headline: Severan Dynasty
text.text:
The Severan dynasty began with Septimius Severus, who came to power in 193 after a civil war. His reign, from 193 to 211, was marked by military and administrative reforms, as well as victorious campaigns in Britain, Mesopotamia, and North Africa. He strengthened imperial authority and reorganized the provinces.

Caracalla, his son, ruled from 211 to 217. He is known for the Edict of Caracalla in 212, which granted Roman citizenship to all free men in the Empire. His reign was also marked by military campaigns and assassinations.

Macrinus, who ruled briefly from 217 to 218, was the first emperor not from the senatorial nobility. He was overthrown by Elagabalus, a 14-year-old priest, who ruled from 218 to 222. Elagabalus's reign was marked by scandals and excesses, leading to his assassination.

Alexander Severus, the last of the dynasty, ruled from 222 to 235. His reign was characterized by reform attempts and campaigns against the Persians and Germans. Alexander Severus's assassination in 235 marked the end of the dynasty and the beginning of the Crisis of the Third Century.

events.territory: Rome, present-day Italy, North Africa, Middle East

text.headline: Diocletian and the Tetrarchy
text.text:
Diocletian, who became emperor in 284, established the Tetrarchy in 293 to stabilize the Empire and better manage internal crises and external invasions. The Tetrarchy divided the Empire into two parts, each governed by an Augustus and a Caesar. Diocletian ruled the East, while Maximian ruled the West. The two Caesars, Constantius Chlorus and Galerius, assisted the Augusti. This reform aimed to share power and reduce the risk of rebellion.

Diocletian also undertook administrative, economic, and military reforms, stabilizing the currency and strengthening the army. He persecuted Christians to restore the old Roman religions. In 305, Diocletian voluntarily abdicated, a first in Roman history, and retired to Dalmatia. The Tetrarchy, however, did not survive long after his departure, as rivalries between the co-emperors led to a series of civil wars culminating in Constantine's victory in 312.

text.headline: Constantine and the Founding of Constantinople
text.text:
Constantine the Great, proclaimed emperor by his troops in 306, is one of the most influential emperors in Roman history. After a series of civil wars, he became the sole emperor in 324. Constantine was the first Christian emperor, and his reign marked the conversion of the Empire to Christianity. In 313, he issued the Edict of Milan, granting freedom of worship to all religions.

In 330, he founded Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul), which became the new capital of the Eastern Roman Empire. Constantinople was strategically located and fortified, serving as a political, economic, and cultural center for the Empire. Constantine also reorganized the army and administration, strengthening imperial power. He convened the Council of Nicaea in 325 to establish a unified Christian doctrine.

His death in 337 left a Christian and centralized Empire, divided among his three sons. Constantine's reign marked a turning point in Roman history, laying the foundations for the Byzantine Empire.

events.territory: Rome, present-day Italy, Constantinople, North Africa, Middle East

text.headline: Western Roman Empire
text.text:
The Western Roman Empire, officially established in 395 after the division of the Empire by Theodosius I, faced constant barbarian invasions and internal crises. Western emperors, such as Honorius, Valentinian III, and Romulus Augustulus, struggled to maintain control against the incursions of Germanic tribes and other barbarian peoples. The sack of Rome by the Visigoths in 410 and by the Vandals in 455 symbolized the decline of the Empire.

The influence of powerful generals, such as Flavius Stilicho, marked this period. Western Roman society was complex and diverse, with a well-defined social hierarchy and urban life centered around fortified cities. The diet included grains, bread, olive oil, vegetables, fruits, fish, and meat. Romans practiced polytheistic religion before adopting Christianity as the state religion under Emperor Constantine. Roman arts and culture flourished, with advances in architecture, sculpture, and literature.

Despite efforts to preserve the Empire, the Western Roman Empire ultimately succumbed to barbarian invasions. In 476, the Germanic leader Odoacer deposed the last emperor, Romulus Augustulus, marking the end of the Western Roman Empire.

text.headline: Eastern Roman Empire
text.text:
The Eastern Roman Empire, also known as the Byzantine Empire, survived the fall of the Western Roman Empire and thrived until the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople in 1453. Founded on the reforms of Diocletian and Constantine, the Byzantine Empire retained many Roman traditions while developing a distinct culture influenced by Orthodox Christianity. The capital, Constantinople, became a major political, economic, and cultural center.

Under the reign of Justinian (527-565), the Empire experienced a revival with the reconquest of North Africa, Italy, and Spain. Justinian also codified Roman law in the Corpus Juris Civilis, which became the basis of civil law in Europe. Byzantine art, characterized by mosaics and religious icons, reached new heights of sophistication.

Despite periods of crisis, such as the Iconoclasm and Arab invasions, the Empire maintained its influence. Byzantine emperors, like Basil II and Alexios I Komnenos, successfully defended and restored the Empire's power. The Byzantine Empire played a crucial role in preserving ancient knowledge and transmitting Greco-Roman culture to medieval Europe.

The fall of Constantinople in 1453 marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, but its legacy endures in the history and culture of Eastern Europe and the Middle East.
